TI Longitudinal field repolarization studies of reorientational dynamics in
   the fullerenes C-60 and C-70
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID MOLECULAR-DYNAMICS; PHASE-TRANSITIONS; MUON
AB LF mu SR studies on the pure fullerenes C-60 and C-70 show temperature dependent features associated with the reorientational behaviour of the fullerenyl radicals MuC(60) and MuC(70) in the crystalline host substrate. If not excluded from the experimental setup, molecular oxygen undergoes spin exchange reactions with the radicals. The data for C-60 correspond to a situation effectively static at 150 K and fully averaged to isotropy at 300 K, while for C-70 the data conspicuously do not conform to the predictions of the pseudostatic model employed in ALC-mu SR studies.

TI Ultra slow muons generated by laser resonant ionization of thermal
   muonium produced by 500-MeV protons with hot tungsten
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID VACUUM
AB We report recent progress to date on the UT-MSL/KEK ''Ultra Slow Muon'' project, in which thermal muonium (Mu) atoms are generated from the surface of a hot tungsten target placed at the primary 500 MeV proton beam line and resonantly ionized by intense u.v. lasers synchronized with the emission of the Mu. The positive muon ionization fragments are collected by electrostatic beam optics to form a beam of slow positive muons.

TI Muonium desorption to vacuum from hot iridium surface
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID THERMAL MUONIUM; HYDROGEN; GENERATION; IONIZATION
AB Slow muonium (Mu) emission from the surface of iridium (Ir) foil has been observed in vacuum above similar to 1200 K With a yield of 5(1)% Mu per incident muon stopped in the foil. The relative Mu signal was found to be thermally activated with E-a = 1.86(1) eV. Analysis of the time-differential evolution of Mu in vacuum at T-Ir = 1580 K showed that the trapping rate of positive muons during diffusion in the bulk Ir was nearly zero. In situ measurements of the surface of Ir with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy verified that the main source of impurities in the 99.9%-Ir was molybdenum (Mo).
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI Theory of hyperfine interactions associated with the negative muon in
   lanthanum copper oxide high T-c system
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID NMR
AB We have carried out first-principles Unrestricted Hartree-Fock Cluster investigations to demonstrate that the Auger holes produced by the entry of mu(-) into the oxygen ions in La2CuO4 lead to stable O(-)mu(-) centers at apical and planar sites. The hyperfine fields associated with these two sites suggest that the apical one is responsible for the stronger and more anisotropic Knight shift in mu SR measurements and the planar for the weaker and less anisotropic shift, the needed susceptibility arising from the localized magnetic moments on the O(-)mu(-) centers. This identification of the susceptibility provides support for the model proposed for the observed increase in mu SR relaxation rate below the superconducting temperatures.

TI Probing interaction of paramagnetic electron with conduction electrons
   in high T-c superconductor LaSrCuO by (mu O-) spin relaxation
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID MU(-)O; SHIFT
AB The paramagnetic (mu(-)O) state formed at the oxygen site in high T-c LaSrCuO was used to probe an interaction between the localized moment of the paramagnetic electron and the conduction electrons via zero field mu(-) spin relaxation. The enhanced relaxation rates consistently observed in the superconducting state of various Sr concentrations are explained as an effect of spin-pairing in the high T-c supercurrent.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,MESON SCI LAB,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI Observation of magnetically ordered state in TlBa2Y1-xCaxCu2Oy by mu+SR
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID SYSTEM; SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; LA2CUO4; PHASE; SR
AB Magnetic properties of TlBa2Y1-xCaxCu2Oy which is one of the hole-doped high-T-c superconducting (SC) oxides were investigated by zero-field mu(+)SR. Two precession frequencies of the muon spin were observed for x = 0, indicating the existence of a coherent long range antiferromagnetic ordered state of Cu-spins. The saturated internal fields at the muon sites, H-int, was 170 Oe and 23 Oe, respectively and magnetic transition temperature, T-N, was about 400 K. Both H-int and T-N show no x-dependence up to x = 0.5. No sign of the magnetic ordered state was observed in the SC state for x = 1.0 down to 1.8 K.
C1 TOHOKU UNIV,FAC SCI,DEPT CHEM,SENDAI,MIYAGI 98077,JAPAN.
   UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,DEPT PHYS,MESON SCI LAB,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.
RP Watanabe, I (reprint author), RIKEN,INST PHYS & CHEM RES,MUON SCI LAB,WAKO,SAITAMA 35101,JAPAN.

TI Quantum diffusion of positive muon in pure tantalum
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID LIGHT INTERSTITIALS; METALS
AB Quantum diffusion of positive muons has been studied in high purity Ta by zero and longitudinal field muon spin relaxation techniques. We found that the muon hopping rate in Ta is more or less the same as in pure Cu (i.e., nu similar or equal to 10(5) similar to 10(6) s(-1)), showing a characteristic temperature dependence proportional to T-alpha with alpha ranging from 2 to 0.2 below 20 K. In addition, a step-like change of the nuclear dipolar width was observed at 60 K associated with the sharp peak of hopping rate, suggesting a change of stable muon sites.
RP Kadono, R (reprint author), RIKEN,INST PHYS & CHEM RES,2-1 HIROSAWA,WAKO,SAITAMA 35101,JAPAN.

TI Mu centers in crystalline Ge under illumination
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID MUONIUM DYNAMICS; SI
AB A slow conversion to a diamagnetic state has been observed for muonium centers at the tetrahedral interstitial site (Mu(T)(0)) in dark Ge at low temperatures. When the conversion process is affected by illumination, no effect of illumination upon the initial (Mu(T)(0)) centers themselves was observed at 10 K. This is in marked contrast with the case of (Mu(T)(0)) centers in Si where strong interaction with photo-induced carriers is observed, suggesting that the electronic level associated with (Mu(T)(0)) state in Ge is not located in the energy gap.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI Muonium centers in heavily n-doped Si under illumination: Evidence for
   Mu-hole interaction
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID DYNAMICS
AB A small fraction of implanted muons exists as a paramagnetic state (presumably Mu(BC)(0), muonium at the Si-Si bond center) in heavily Sb-doped Si (n-type, [Sb] similar or equal to 10(18) cm(-3)). The paramagnetic state is susceptible to illumination both at 10-20 K and 290 K, providing evidence that holes (minority carriers) play an important role in determining the dynamical properties of muonium centers, where change may occur via a process Mu(BC)(0) + h(+) --> Mu(BC)(+) followed by charge exchange reaction (or transition Mu(BC)(+) + e(-) --> Mu(T)(0)).
RP Kadono, R (reprint author), RIKEN,INST PHYS & CHEM RES,2-1 HIROSAWA,WAKO,SAITAMA 35101,JAPAN.
CR CHOW KH, 1993, PHYS REV B, V47, P16004, DOI 10.1103/PhysRevB.47.16004

TI Appearance of magnetic long range order in the spin ladder compound
   LaCuO2.5
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; GAPS
AB We report here the two current topics in the ladder compounds.
   1. The new ladder compound LaCuO2.5 recently discovered by Hiroi and Takano shows a clear sign of magnetic long range order at around 125 K observed by mu(+)SR technique. This result demonstrates that the ground state of LaCuO2.5 is not a spin liquid state, but a magnetically ordered state.
   2. Superconductivity has been found in the ladder material (Sr,Ca)(14)Cu24O41 under high pressure between 3 GPa and 4.5 GPa. The superconducting transition temperatures T-c (onset) are 12 K and 9 K at 3 GPa and 4.5 GPa, respectively.
C1 RIKEN,INST PHYS & CHEM RES,WAKO,SAITAMA 35101,JAPAN.
   KYOTO UNIV,INST CHEM RES,UJI,KYOTO 611,JAPAN.

TI mu SR measurements of BaNiO2
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID STATE
AB We performed magnetic susceptibility, heat capacity and muon spin relaxation measurements of BaNiO2, which has zigzag chains of Ni2+ ions. The results show that BaNiO2 is in a non-magnetic state at low temperatures.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,DEPT PHYS,MESON SCI LAB UTMSL,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI Zero-field mu SR study of antiferromagnetic Ce(Ru1-xRhx)(2)Si-2
   heavy-fermion compound
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID SPIN-ROTATION
AB Zero-field mu SR measurements have been carried out on high-quality single-crystal samples of the antiferromagnetic heavy-fermion compound Ce(Ru1-xRhx)(2)Si-2 for x = 0.15 from 2 K to 300 K. The mu SR signal with the muon beam parallel to the c-axis does not show any definite change in its time spectrum. The mu SR signal perpendicular to the c-axis indicates appearance of the spin relaxation at about 6 K with a rapid increase of its rate as a decrease of temperature. This is interpreted in terms of occurrence of inhomogeneous static fields along the c-axis due to incommensurable sinusoidal spin ordering along the c-axis. The held distribution deduced from the mu SR time spectrum is consistent with an SDW ordering.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.
   OSAKA UNIV,FAC SCI,DEPT PHYS,TOYONAKA,OSAKA 560,JAPAN.

TI mu SR study of the magnetic ordering in Ce1-xLaxRu2Si2
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
AB Zero-field mu SR measurements have been carried out in the paramagnetic and magnetically ordered states of the heavy fermion alloys: Ce1-xLaxRu2Si2 (x = 0.05, 0.13, 0.25). In Ce1-xLaxRu2Si2 system, T-K drastically decreases with x from 24 K for x = 0 and becomes very close to the magnetic ordering temperature T-N. As functions of T-K and T-N, the magnetic instabilities were studied in this system. For x = 0.05, 0.13 and 0.25 samples, longitudinal muon spin relaxation was measured to study non-magnetic to magnetic transition and the change from itinerant to localized electron state with increasing La impurities. We discuss the dynamics of muon spins in the paramagnetic and antiferromagnetic state.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.
RP Yamamoto, Y (reprint author), OSAKA UNIV,GRAD SCH SCI,DEPT EARTH & SPACE SCI,TOYONAKA,OSAKA 560,JAPAN.

TI Studies of diluted antiferromagnets MnxMg1-xTiO3 with x=0.55 and 0.70 by
   muon spin relaxation method
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
AB Longitudinal fields mu SR measurements have been performed in order to probe the spin dynamics in the diluted antiferromagnets MnxMg1-xTiO3 with x = 0.70 and 0.55. In the x = 0.70 sample which forms the antiferromagnetic long-range order, the static and fluctuating fields coexist at the muon stopping site below T-N. On the other hand, in the x = 0.55 sample which shows the spin-glass behavior, the local fields fluctuate rather fast even below T-SG. We infer that this drastic change occurs when MnxMg1-xTiO3 transforms from an antiferromagnetic system to a spin-glass system by dilution.

TI The spin dynamics of the cluster-glass Fe0.25Mg0.75TiO3 probed by the
   muon spin relaxation method
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID PERCOLATION CONCENTRATION; ANTIFERROMAGNET
AB A cluster-glass (CG) Fe0.25Mg0.75TiO3 is investigated by muon spin relaxation measurements. It is found that the local magnetic fields at the muon stopping site are established at temperatures five times as high as the freezing temperature T-f. It is also found that the electron spins fluctuate even below T-f. The critical region around T-f in Fe0.25Mg0.75TiO3 is extremely wide in contrast to that of ordinary spin-glass (SG) systems. It is clearly demonstrated that the microscopic and dynamical properties of CG are remarkably different from those of SG.

TI Muon spin relaxation in diluted triangular-lattice antiferromagnet
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 7th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation, Relaxation,
   Resonance
CY APR 15-19, 1996
CL NIKKO, JAPAN
SP Univ Tokyo, Meson Sci Lab, Inst Phys & Chem Res, Muon Sci Lab
ID PHASE-TRANSITION; LUFEMGO4; SYSTEM
AB Zero and longitudinal field mu SR measurements on diluted triangular-lattice antiferromagnet LuFeMgO4 have revealed gradual and highly anisotropic slowing-down of spin fluctuation. Relaxation rate lambda in the condition with initial muon spins perpendicular to the hexagonal c-plane shows divergent behavior while that in the parallel configuration remains finite. At certain temperature range the fluctuation of spins is suppressed by a small external magnetic field. Monte Carlo calculation suggests that the correlation time for z(c)-component of spins diverges first on cooling.

TI Muon studies of spin dynamics in polyaniline
SO SYNTHETIC METALS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Conference on the Science and Technology of Synthetic
   Metals
CY JUL 28-AUG 02, 1996
CL SNOWBIRD, UT
SP Univ Utah, Elsevier Sci SA, Los Alamos Nat Lab, Monsanto, Off Naval Res, US Dept Energy, Bayer Corp, Taiwan United Microelec Corp, Uniax
DE polyaniline and derivatives
ID POLYACETYLENE
AB The muon is a valuable probe of spin excitations in polymers, as the muon implantation process itself generates a lest excitation whose dynamical properties can be studied via the evolution of the muon spin polarisation. We report here studies on undoped polyaniline in its emeraldine base form (PANI:EB). Characteristic field dependences and cutoff frequencies for the muon spin relaxation are observed which are related to the spin diffusion. One-dimensional diffusion is seen at low temperatures and at short probe times. The on chain diffusion is observed to have a weak metallic temperature dependence whereas the interchain diffusion is strongly activated and phenyl ring rotations are seen to have an important effect on the diffusion processes.

TI Superconducting and magnetic ordered states in TlBa2Y1-xCaxCu2Oy studied
   by mu(+)SR
SO JOURNAL OF LOW TEMPERATURE PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Conference on Physics and Chemistry of Molecular and Oxide
   Superconductors
CY AUG 02-06, 1996
CL KARLSRUHE, GERMANY
ID SYSTEM; PHASE; SR
AB Hole doped high-T-C oxide of TlBa2 Y1-xCaxCu2Oy, Tl-1212, has been investigated by mu(+)SR technique from an insulating to a superconducting (SC) region. Fast and slow precession, components of the muon spin asymmetry which are due to an. antiferromagnetic (AF) ordering of Cu-spins were observed from x = 0 to x = 0.5. The magnetic transition temperature (about 400 K) and local mu(+) fields were found to have no x-dependence. No sign of the magnetic transition was observed for x = 1.0 down to 1.8 K. The correlation between the AF ordered state and the SC state at the boundary of the two states (x = 0.6) was examined.

TI Intense proton accelerator of Japanese Hadron project as a basis for
   mu(+)mu(-) colliders
SO NUCLEAR PHYSICS B
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Symposium on Physics Potential and Development of mu(plus)mu(minus)
   Colliders
CY DEC 13-15, 1995
CL SAN FRANCISCO, CA
ID SLOW
AB The Japanese Hadron Project which is now under serious considerations as a next generation of high intensity proton accelerator can be considered as a basic for mu(+)mu(-) colliders. At the same time, the ideas for providing intense high-quality eV to keV muons proposed in the eighties have been successfully realized recently These ultra-slow muons will have a possible large-scale application to an eventual mu(+)mu(-) collider.

TI Long-range magnetic ordering in the spin ladder compound LaCuO2.5 probed
   by muon-spin relaxation
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW B
LA English
DT Article
ID SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; SRN-1CUN+1O2N; 2-LEG; GAPS
AB A clear sign of long-range magnetic ordering has been observed by muon-spin rotation/relaxation in the two-leg spin-ladder compound LaCuO0.25, below 125 K with a relatively large hyperfine field (similar to 0.1 T). This result demonstrates that the ground state of the undoped LaCuO2.5 is a magnetically ordered state, rather than the predicted quantum spin-liquid state.

TI An unusually small muon-electron coupling constant - Muonium addition to
   biacetyl
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID SPIN-RESONANCE; INTERNAL-ROTATION; FREE-RADICALS; SPECTRA; DYNAMICS;
   LIQUIDS; BOND
AB The room temperature muon-electron coupling constant in the 2-muoxy-3-ketobut-2-yl radical formed by muonium addition to biacetyl (butane-2,3-dione) has been measured by two separate techniques (time-differential transverse field muon spin rotation and 500 MHz rf muon spin resonance spectroscopy) and corresponds to a H-1 equivalent of 0.65 MHz, the smallest room temperature alpha-hydroxyl coupling so far measured in any radical. Its value is examined in the light of ab initio Hartree-Fock calculations and commented on in the context of the electronic structure of the radical and its relation to that of the parent molecule.

TI Isolation of cDNA for a novel human protein KNP-I that is homologous to
   the E. coli SCRP-27A protein from the autoimmune polyglandular disease
   type I (APECED) region of chromosome 21q22.3
SO BIOCHEMICAL AND BIOPHYSICAL RESEARCH COMMUNICATIONS
LA English
DT Article
ID LOCUS; SITE
AB We have isolated cDNA clones for a novel human protein KNP-I from fetal brain and bone marrow cDNA libraries. Northern blot analysis indicated that the KNP-I gene is ubiquitously expressed in various human tissues. Significant homology of the KNP-I protein with Escherichia coli anti-sigma cross-reacting protein (SCRP-27A) (44% identity and zebrafish (Brachydanio rerio) es1 protein (49% identity) suggested that thr KNP-I protein may be involved in a basic cellular function, Genomic sequencing revealed that the KNP-I gene consists of seven exons spanning 12 kb. Exon 5 was involved in alternative splicing. The KNP-I gene was mapped between D21S1460 and D21S25 on human chromosome 21q22.3, 26 kb distal to a Not I site of D21S1460. Thus, this novel KNP-I gene could be a candidate gene for autoimmune polyglandular disease type I (APECED) and other disorders mapped to this region. (C) 1996 Academic Press, Inc.

TI Muonium emission into vacuum from tungsten and iridium surfaces
SO SURFACE SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 13th International Vacuum Congress/9th International Conference on Solid
   Surfaces (IVC-13/ICSS-9)
CY SEP 25-29, 1995
CL YOKOHAMA, JAPAN
DE atom-solid interactions; atom-solid reactions; iridium; oxidation;
   thermionic emission; tungsten; tungsten oxide; X-ray photoelectron
   spectroscopy
AB Thermal-energy muonium (Mu) emission was observed from the surfaces of tungsten and iridium foils heated above 1000 K with a yield of similar to 10(-2) Mu per incident mu(+), The spatial distribution of Mu as a function of time from tungsten covered with oxide layers was observed, and the desorption rate of Mu from the oxide-layer surface was found to be similar to 10(7) s(-1). The oxide layer was verified to be similar to 4 x 10(13) molecules cm(-2) W2O6 by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Also, Mu emission into a vacuum was evidenced from the surface of oxide-layer free iridium.

   Nagamine, K
TI Muonium emission to a vacuum from metallic and oxidized surfaces of
   high-purity polycrystalline tungsten
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
AB A thermal-energy muonium (Mu) was observed in a vacuum from the surface of 99.9998%-pure tungsten foil at 1500 K with a yield of 8(1)% Mu per incident muon stopped in the foil. The yield was explained by the one-dimensional diffusion constant of a positive muon in tungsten at 1500 K, measured to be 1.3(2)x10(-2) cm(2)s(-1), about 70 times higher than that of hydrogen. The desorption rate of Mu was estimated to be approximate to 10(7) s(-1) from the time evolution of the spatial distribution of Mu from tungsten covered with oxide layers. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy verified that the surface was covered with approximate to 4x10(13) molecules cm(-2) of W2O6.

TI Muonium quadrupole interactions in alpha-quartz under uniaxial pressure:
   Room temperature anisotropy
SO PHYSICS LETTERS A
LA English
DT Article
DE quartz; muonium spin rotation (MuSR); uniaxial pressure; quadrupole
   moment; hydrogen/muonium hyperfine interactions; hydrogen/muonium
   dynamics; crystalline electric fields (gradient); dauphine twinning
AB The uniaxial pressure dependence (0 to 0.4 GPa) of the quadrupole interaction tensor of muonium in alpha-quartz was measured in a 5 G transverse field and zero field at room temperature using muonium spin relaxation, The quadrupole splitting frequency is linearly dependent on the applied pressure. For pressures applied along the c-axis of quartz, the slope of the quadrupole frequency splitting with respect to c/a has the opposite sign of the previously obtained temperature dependence measurements. For pressure applied perpendicular to the c-axis of quartz, the axial symmetry of the hyperfine tensor is broken yielding a fully anisotropic hyperfine structure. A qualitative explanation for these effects is proposed.

TI Gas geochemical changes at mineral springs associated with the 1995
   southern Hyogo earthquake (M=7.2), Japan
SO EARTH AND PLANETARY SCIENCE LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Kobe Japan; Hyogo earthquake 1995; earthquake prediction;
   hydrochemistry; argon; helium; nitrogen
ID ANOMALIES; ORIGIN
AB Gas concentrations monitored at a mineral spring in central Japan over the past 15 years showed similar changes before and after two large earthquakes (September 1984, M = 6.9, 50 km distant: and January 1995, M = 7.2, 220 km distant); namely, a concurrent and abrupt drop in all three gas ratios, He/Ar, N-2/Ar, and CH4/Ar, several months before the events. Improved measurements of gas compositions since 1991 and the addition of gas discharge rate monitoring since 1993 disclosed the following features for anomalies in response to small earthquakes as well as the large 1995 event: (1) the gas ratios increased for both large and small earthquakes, but they did not return to the preseismic values for the large event, as they did within a few hours for the small events; (2) at the 1995 event, the gas discharge rate decreased remarkably 3 h before the event and then increased to higher than preseismic level for several months. In contrast, coseismic rates at small events generally increased for less than 15 min; (3) during a seismically quiet period, from January 1993 to December 1994, the variation in the He/Ar ratio was well correlated with that of gas discharge rate. Such correlation disappeared in August and September, 1994, when the three gas ratios dropped before the large event; (4) gas compositions at an auxiliary monitoring site revealed a coseismic change similar to that described above for the 1995 event. These lines of evidence show that subsurface fluids may habitually respond to changes in physical conditions relating to earthquake occurrences, and thus suggest the usefulness of monitoring subsurface fluids for earthquake prediction.
C1 NAGOYA UNIV,GRAD SCH HUMAN INFORMAT,NAGOYA,AICHI 46401,JAPAN.

TI Muon catalyzed fusion experiments on muonic deuterium atom deceleration
   in thin solid deuterium films
SO PHYSICS LETTERS B
LA English
DT Article
DE muonic hydrogen atom; muonic atom scattering; muon catalyzed fusion;
   solid hydrogen; thin film; slow muon production
ID DD FUSION; 150-K; 25-K
AB Muon catalyzed fusion was investigated in a series of thin solid deuterium films by detecting protons from dd fusion. Two different contributions to the total fusion yield resulting from d mu atoms emitted from a primary hydrogen layer and from incident muons directly stopped in the deuterium film itself were observed. The thickness dependence of the fusion yield suggested the importance of molecular effects in d mu elastic scattering in D-2.

TI Microscopic studies of positive muon behavior in solid H-2 and D-2
SO CZECHOSLOVAK JOURNAL OF PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 21st International Conference on Low Temperature Physics (LT 21)
CY AUG 08-14, 1996
CL PRAGUE, CZECH REPUBLIC
SP Int Union Pure & Appl Phys
ID HYDROGEN; RELAXATION
AB Using pulsed muon beam, we have investigated microscopic positive muon(mu(+)) behaviors in solid para-H-2(I=0,J=0) and ortho-D-2(I=0,2,J=0) down to 0.6K by muon spin rotation/relaxation (mu(+)SR) method. From the studies of mu(+) spin relaxation phenomena, we have found that mu(+) takes three types of microscopic states;H-2 mu(+)(D-2 mu(+))(20 similar to 25%), muonium (mu(+)e(-),15 similar to 20%) and mu(+)(similar to 60%). In the H-2 mu(+) molecule, as mu(+) has been found to feel much smaller magnetic field expected from the magnetic moments of two protons, H-2 mu(+) molecule is speculated to be in the rotational excited state. Muonium and mu(+) have been found to diffuse around in the crystal. These are considered as quantum diffusion and the diffusion rate of muonium is found to be two order of magnitude larger than that of mu(+).

TI mu(+)SR study on magnetic state of TlBa2Y1-xCaxCu2Oy
SO CZECHOSLOVAK JOURNAL OF PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 21st International Conference on Low Temperature Physics (LT 21)
CY AUG 08-14, 1996
CL PRAGUE, CZECH REPUBLIC
SP Int Union Pure & Appl Phys
ID SYSTEM; SR
AB Temperature and dopant concentration dependence of magnetic properties of TlBa2Y1-xCaxCu2Oy were investigated by mu(+)SR at RIKEN-RAL Muon Facility. Fast and slow coherent precession of the muon spin were observed up to x=0.5, proving the existence of a long range antiferromagnetic ordered state of Cu-spins. The magnetic transition temperature was about 400 K and showed x-independence up to x=0.5.

TI Generation of ultra-slow muons for large-scale future applications
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Proceedings of the International Symposium on Exotic Atoms and Nuclei in
   Honor of Professor T Yamazakis 60th Birthday
CY JUN 07-10, 1995
CL HAKONE, JAPAN
AB The ideas of providing intense high-quality eV to keV muons (mu(+)mu(-)) proposed in the eighties have been tested during the last five years. Recently, remarkable success was marked for ultra-slow mu(+), while a promising test result was obtained for ultra-slow mu(-). The ultimate future of these beams is considered. A possible large-scale application to an eventual mu(+)mu(-) collider is discussed.

TI Muon transfer in excited states of muonic hydrogen probed by Lyman
   X-rays with an advanced Si(Li) detector
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article
ID D-T FUSION; CHARGE-EXCHANGE; MESIC ATOMS; COLLISIONS; KINETICS; ISOTOPES
AB A study on the muon transfer reaction in the excited states of muonic hydrogen has been started at the pulsed muon facility of UT-MSL in the National Laboratory for High Energy Physics (KEK). Muonic X-rays from a mixture of protium and deuterium were detected and resolved successfully with a high-resolution si(Li) X-ray detector. q(1s) for a low-density pd mixture was obtained with this elegant method.

TI New RIKEN-RAL pulsed mu CF facility and X-ray studies on DT-mu CF
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Symposium on Muon Catalyzed Fusion and the Physics of
   Exotic Atoms and Molecules (muCF-95)
CY JUN 19-24, 1995
CL DUBNA, RUSSIA
ID FUSION
AB In November 1994, the construction of a new superconducting muon channel of the RIKEN-RAL muon facility at ISIS of Rutherford Appleton Laboratory was completed. Subsequently, important features, such as the highest instantaneous intensity with a single-pulse structure and a high purity have been confirmed. Along with the installation of advanced mu CF experimental equipment, including a high-purity D-T mixture target system with an in situ He-3 removal capability and a 4 T confinement magnet, an advanced mu CF experiment, e.g. a precise X-ray measurement on mu-alpha sticking in dt mu-mu CF will. be realized. An account of the commissioning experiments, a plan for the earliest phase of the mu CF experiment and possible future directions are reported.

TI mu CF experiments in thin deuterium films and progress towards slow
   mu(-) production
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Symposium on Muon Catalyzed Fusion and the Physics of
   Exotic Atoms and Molecules (muCF-95)
CY JUN 19-24, 1995
CL DUBNA, RUSSIA
ID CATALYZED FUSION; SOLID HYDROGEN
AB Muon-catalyzed fusion was investigated in thin solid deuterium films to determine the experimental feasibility of slow mu(-) production by detection of dd fusion protons as well as slow mu(-) collection utilizing a large-acceptance magnetic spectrometer. The spatial distribution of the fusion reaction in the film was extracted, and an optimum thickness for slow mu(-) emission was deduced. Collected 10 keV mu(-) were also successfully detected. However, the dd fusion yield being insufficient, we were not able to distinguish slow mu(-) via mu CF from degraded mu(-).

TI mu SR studies of YFeMnO4
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 10th International Conference on Hyperfine Interactions
CY AUG 28-SEP 01, 1995
CL LOUVAIN, BELGIUM
SP Katholieke Univ Leuven, Inst Kernen Stralingsfysika
ID SINGLE-CRYSTAL; ANTIFERROMAGNET; MAGNETIZATION; MOSSBAUER; SYSTEM
AB Muon spin relaxation (mu SR) studies were carried out on YFeMnO4. Two interesting phenomena were found in measurements of longitudinal relaxation time spectra at T > T-cusp for a single crystal: (1) difference of the relaxation rates between the directions parallel with and perpendicular to the c-axis, and (2) suppression of local field fluctuations in a longitudinal external field. The spectra at T > T-cusp were reproduced with the function exp[-(lambda(0)t)(beta)]. The results are discussed under a picture of the magnetic spin fluctuations of triangular antiferromagnets.

TI Interaction of paramagnetic electron with high T-c supercurrent in
   LaSrCuO studied by (mu O--) probe
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 10th International Conference on Hyperfine Interactions
CY AUG 28-SEP 01, 1995
CL LOUVAIN, BELGIUM
SP Katholieke Univ Leuven, Inst Kernen Stralingsfysika
AB The paramagnetic state of the muonic atom formed by the negative muon (mu(-)) bound to the oxygen in high T-c LaSrCuO which was found in our recent mu(-) spin rotation experiments was applied to probe an interaction between the paramagnetic electron and the high T-c supercurrent. The observed enhanced spin relaxation rates of the (mu(-)O) system in the superconducting state revealed the presence of such an interaction.

TI MU-SR STUDIES ON SPIN-PEIERLS SYSTEM CU1-XZNXGEO3 (X=0, 0.01, 1.03, AND
   0.07)
SO JOURNAL OF THE PHYSICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
LA English
DT Article
DE MU-SR; SPIN-PEIERLS TRANSITION; SPIN GLASS TRANSITION; CUGEO3
ID TRANSITION; CUGEO3
AB The zero-field and the longitudinal field spin-relaxations of positive muon (mu(+)) were measured in Cu1-xZnxGeO3 (x=0, 0.01, 0.03, and 0.07) to study the spin-Peierls system. The obtained relaxation functions were separated into two components below T-SP in CuGeO3. We conclude that the fast relaxation is originated from a few CU2+ spins being not coupled with spin-singlet state, and that the slow relaxation is due to the nuclear dipolar fields. The fast relaxation function shape changes to the Gaussian at 5 K in the sample of x=0.07. The system changes from the static diluted to the densed one. We also confirmed the appearances of the spin-glass-like relaxations at 5 K in the samples of x=0.03 and 0.07.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI EVOLUTION OF LIGHT-HYDROCARBON GASES IN SUBSURFACE PROCESSES -
   CONSTRAINTS FROM CHEMICAL-EQUILIBRIUM
SO EARTH AND PLANETARY SCIENCE LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID CARBON ISOTOPE GEOCHEMISTRY; NATURAL GASES; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS;
   ORIGIN; TEMPERATURES; FLUIDS; BASIN; JAPAN
AB The behaviour of CH4, C2H6 and C3H8 in subsurface processes such as magma intrusion, volcanic gas discharge and natural gas generation have been examined from the viewpoint of chemical equilibrium. It seems that equilibrium among these three hydrocarbons is attainable at about 200 degrees C. When a system at high temperatures is cooled, re-equilibration is continued until a low temperature is reached. The rate at which re-equilibration is achieved, however, steadily diminishes and, below 200 degrees C, the reaction between the hydrocarbons stops and the gas composition at this time is frozen in, and it remains unchanged in a metastable state for a long period of geological time. Natural gas compositions from various fields have shown that, when a hydrocarbon system out of chemical equilibrium is heated, it gradually approaches equilibrium above 150 degrees C. On the way towards equilibration, compositions of thermogenic gases apparently temporarily show a thermodynamic equilibrium constant at a temperature that is higher than the real equilibrium temperature expected from the ambient temperature of the samples; in contrast, biogenic gases indicate a lower temperature. In lower temperature regions, kinetic effects probably control the gas composition; the compositions are essentially subjected to genetic processes operating on the gases (such as pyrolysis of organic material and bacterial activity) and they fluctuate substantially. Examination of volcanic gases and pyrolysis experimental data, however, have suggested that the equilibration rate of these hydrocarbons is sluggish in comparison with that of reactive inorganic species such as H2S and SO2. The view presented in this study will be helpful in understanding the genetic processes that create oil and gas and the migration of these hydrocarbons and in interpreting the origins of magmatic gases.
C1 NAGOYA UNIV,DEPT NUCL ENGN,NAGOYA,AICHI 46401,JAPAN.

TI METHOD OF PROBING INNER-STRUCTURE OF GEOPHYSICAL SUBSTANCE WITH THE
   HORIZONTAL COSMIC-RAY MUONS AND POSSIBLE APPLICATION TO
   VOLCANIC-ERUPTION PREDICTION
SO NUCLEAR INSTRUMENTS & METHODS IN PHYSICS RESEARCH SECTION A-ACCELERATORS
   SPECTROMETERS DETECTORS AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT
LA English
DT Article
AB One potential use of cosmic-ray muons arriving nearly horizontally along the earth is a probe of the inner-structure of a gigantic geophysical substance, such as a volcanic mountain. A simple detection system comprising a plastic scintillator hodoscope which is expandable to a larger scale was developed. The first successful measurement of the inner-structure of Mt. Tsukuba is described. The future perspective of the application of the present method towards the prediction of volcanic eruption is discussed.

TI MUONIUM QUADRUPOLE INTERACTIONS IN ALPHA-QUARTZ AT ELEVATED-TEMPERATURES
SO PHYSICS LETTERS A
LA English
DT Article
ID TRANSFORMATION
AB Muonium spin rotation was used to measure quadrupole interactions in the alpha and beta phases of quartz (300-900 K). A marked increase with increasing temperature was observed in the quadrupole frequency splitting (maximum width at the phase transition) which is linearly correlated with the lattice constant ratio c/a. Qualitative explanations of these observed effects are examined. Electric field gradient calculations and relaxation rates are also discussed.

TI MU-SR STUDIES OF SPIN EXCITATIONS IN POLYANILINE
SO SYNTHETIC METALS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 13th International Conference on Science and Technology of Synthetic
   Metals (ICSM 94)
CY JUL 24-29, 1994
CL SEOUL, SOUTH KOREA
AB Muon techniques have been used to study the spill excitations in polyaniline. The relaxation rate provides information about the spin dynamics. 1D spin diffusion is observed at low temperature in non-metallic materials with a crossover to 2 or 3D behaviour at higher temperature. In metallic polyaniline, in contrast to the undoped cases, the relaxation is rapidly quenched by field at all temperatures. Static and dynamic terms in the relaxation can be separated. The dynamic term shows a high field cutoff which occurs around 25 G at 20 K. This relaxation behaviour indicates a broad spectrum of spin fluctuations concentrated at frequencies in the region below 0.3 MHz. This is a frequency region that is somewhat lower than previously studied by other probes of spin dynamics.

AB LaNi3 shows a non-ferromagmetic ordered phase in zero field below about 50 K, and metamagnetism in non-zero field. Zero-field mu SR spectra show an antiferromagnetic phase below about 50 K. From the longitudinal-field mu SR spectra, small Ni moments of about 0.03(mu B) are estimated.

TI PHOTORESPONSIVE MELITTIN HAVING A SPIROPYRAN RESIDUE IN THE HYDROPHOBIC
   REGION OF THE SEQUENCE
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY-PERKIN TRANSACTIONS 2
LA English
DT Article
ID BILAYER-MEMBRANE; ACID
AB A melittin derivative carrying a spiropyran group at the third residue (MSp) was prepared by a semisynthetic method. MSp showed reversible photochromism in a phospholipid bilayer membrane. The kinetics of thermal decolouration and the maximum absorption of MSp in the merocyanine form indicated that the merocyanine moiety is located at the membrane surface. The disturbance of the membrane structure by MSp, as studied by CF leakage, was enhanced by UV-light irradiation. The kinetics of CF leakage indicate that MSp in the merocyanine form disturbs the membrane structure more significantly than that in the spiropyran form.

TI LASER SYSTEM FOR THE RESONANT IONIZATION OF HYDROGEN-LIKE ATOMS PRODUCED
   BY NUCLEAR-REACTIONS
SO NUCLEAR INSTRUMENTS & METHODS IN PHYSICS RESEARCH SECTION B-BEAM
   INTERACTIONS WITH MATERIALS AND ATOMS
LA English
DT Article
ID VACUUM-ULTRAVIOLET; LYMAN-ALPHA; GENERATION; RADIATION; KRYPTON;
   FLUORESCENCE; MUONIUM; XENON
AB We report on the generation of intense pulsed VUV laser radiation of the Lyman-alpha wavelength of hydrogen-like atoms and muonium by a four wave mixing process in a mixture of krypton and argon gas.  The pulse energy was of the order of approximately 1 muJ/pulse at a 20 Hz repetition rate.  The 200 GHz band-width corresponds to the Doppler width of muonium at 2300 K.  With an additional ionizing laser, the one-photon resonant atomic transitions, 1S double-line arrow pointing right 2P double-line arrow pointing right unbound, can be realized for thermal hydrogen-like atoms produced by nuclear reactions as well as for muonium.  Anticipating the need for long term operation, a completely solid-state laser system was chosen for the pumping, oscillators and amplifiers.  The system construction and performance are described together with the results concerning resonant ionization of thermal hydrogen atoms produced by high energy nuclear reactions.

TI MAGNETIC ORDER AND SUPPRESSION OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY AROUND X=0.12 IN
   LA2-XSRXCUO4 AND LA2-XBAXCUO4
SO PHYSICA C
LA English
DT Article
ID TEMPERATURE STRUCTURAL TRANSITION; NUCLEAR HEAT-CAPACITY; CU SPIN
   MOMENTS; (LA1-XBAX)2CUO4; ANOMALIES
AB Although there exists an antiferromagnetic order of Cu-moments around x=0.115 in La2-xSrxCuO4 (LSCO) as similar to La2-xBaxCuO4, x-ray diffraction and transport measurements reveal no evidences of the structural transition to the LTT phase in LSCO. The results suggest that the structural change is not a primary cause of the suppression of superconductivity at the particular composition around x=0.12, but the freezing of spin fluctuations of Cu-moments may play critical role for the anomalies of the La-systems.

TI STUDIES ON DYNAMICS OF MU-REACTION WITH NO2 BY MUON SPIN-RESONANCE AND
   RELAXATION TECHNIQUES
SO JOURNAL OF CHEMICAL PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article
ID THERMAL UNIMOLECULAR REACTIONS; RATE CONSTANTS; LOW-PRESSURES; REACTION
   H; GAS-PHASE; + NO2; KINETICS; PRODUCT
AB The reaction of Mu with NO2 in a Kr atmosphere was studied by muon spin resonance and relaxation measurements at 300 K. It was found that the reaction proceeds via the following two steps: Mu+NO2-->MuO+NO and MuO+NO2-->MuNO(3). In particular, the final product MuNO(3) and the intermediate species MuO were successfully detected for the first time by the techniques of the muon spin resonance and the longitudinal relaxation under a high magnetic field of similar to 2800 G. The rate constants of the Mu+NO2 and the MuO+NO2 reactions were determined to be (2.9+/-0.5)X10(11) e mol(-1) s(-1) and (4.5+/-0.1)X10(9) e mol(-1) s(-1) at 300 K. The isotope effect in the rate constant of the Mu+NO2 reaction in comparison with the H+NO2 reaction suggests that there are reaction paths with a slight energy barrier which is high enough to retard the H reaction, but not the Mu reaction. On the other hand, the rate constant of the MuO+NO2 reaction is smaller than 50% of those of the OH+NO2 and the OD+NO2 reactions. This isotope effect seems to originate from faster rotational motion of MuO and/or lower vibrational density of states at the transition state.

TI ORIGIN AND COSEISMIC BEHAVIOR OF MINERAL SPRING GAS AT BYAKKO, JAPAN,
   STUDIED BY AUTOMATED GAS-CHROMATOGRAPHIC ANALYSES
SO CHEMICAL GEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
ID NATURAL GASES; CARBON; HYDROGEN; RATIOS
AB The origin and coseismic behavior of mineral spring gas were examined on the basis of continual monitoring data for several ps species. The automatic monitoring system used in this study consists of two gas chromatographs and a personal computer. Several ps species can simultaneously be analyzed with these analyzers. The system was so stable and sensitive that minute coseismic anomalies in these species could be detected. A positive correlation between N2/Ar and CH4/Ar implies that the mineral spring gas is a mixture of atmospheric air and lithospheric gas. The lithospheric ps is mainly composed of N2 and CH4, and also contains trace amounts of He. It is inferred from isotopic data that lithospheric N2 and CH4 are thermogenic and He is mostly radiogenic. In contrast, O2 and H-2, in trace amounts, show large diurnal fluctuations, suggesting that these species should be mostly biogenic. Ten earthquakes felt around the station occurred during the monitoring period, and four of them coincided with coseismic anomalies in the He/Ar ratio. The anomalies may be interpreted as follows: by the ground motion at these felt quakes, He accumulated in the ground was additionally released into the spring water. The continual monitoring of these gas species enables us to discuss in detail the origin and behavior of the spring gas and to evaluate background noise of the data.

AU SULAIMAN, SB

TI THEORY OF THE LOCATION AND ASSOCIATED HYPERFINE PROPERTIES OF THE
   POSITIVE MUON IN LA2CUO4
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW B
LA English
DT Article
ID NUCLEAR-QUADRUPOLE INTERACTIONS; HIGH-TC SUPERCONDUCTORS; SPIN-ROTATION;
   TRANSITION-TEMPERATURE; MOSSBAUER-SPECTROSCOPY; ELECTRON DISTRIBUTIONS;
   MAGNETIC-RESONANCE; YBA2CU3O7-DELTA; RELAXATION; NMR
AB The location of the positive muon, used as a tool for probing the magnetic properties of high-T(c) systems, is investigated for La2CuO4. Our calculations, using the unrestricted Hartree-Fock cluster procedure, indicate that the muon is located in the a-c plane, at a distance of 1.08 angstrom from the apical oxygen, with the mu+-O(a) direction making an angle of 25-degrees with the O(a)-Cu direction. The magnitude and direction of the hyperfine field at the equilibrium position are determined. Our results, which are in reasonable agreement with muSR data in powdered samples and single crystals, show the importance of including the local contact and dipolar contributions to the hyperfine field associated with the unpaired spin distribution in the neighborhood of the muon. Possible additional factors that could lead to a bridging of the remaining quantitative differences with experimental hyperfine data will be discussed.
C1 YAMANASHI UNIV, DEPT ELECT ENGN & COMP SCI, KOFU, YAMANASHI 400, JAPAN.

TI MAGNETIC ORDER AND EVOLUTION OF THE ELECTRONIC-STATE AROUND X = 0.12 IN
   LA2-XBAXCUO4 AND LA2-XSRXCUO4
SO JOURNAL OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY
LA English
DT Article
DE HIGH-T(C) SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; MAGNETIC ORDER; MU-SR; LA2-XSRXCAO4
ID TEMPERATURE STRUCTURAL TRANSITION; NUCLEAR HEAT-CAPACITY; MUON-SPIN
   ROTATION; PHASE-TRANSITION; SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; ANOMALIES; MOMENTS;
   X=0.12; TRANSPORT
AB Muon spin rotation (mu+SR) measurement provides clear evidence of the antiferromagnetic order of Cu moments below 35 K for La2-xBaxCuO4 and below 15 K for La2-xSrCuO4 in the narrow range of x where the high-T(c) superconductivity (SC) is suppressed remarkably. The results suggest that the change of the electronic state coupled with the lattice instability is relevant to the local suppression of SC and freezing of spin fluctuations of the Cu moment.

TI POSITIVE MUON SPIN ROTATION STUDY ON MAGNETIC ORDER IN LA2XMXCUO4
   (M=BA,SR) AROUND X=0.12
SO PHYSICA B
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 20th International Conference on Low Temperature Physics
CY AUG 04-11, 1993
CL EUGENE, OR
SP INT UNION PURE & APPL PHYS, AMER PHYS SOC, CITY EUGENE, INT INST REFRIGERAT, INT SCI FDN, JET PROPULS LABS, NATL SCI FDN, USN, OFF NAVAL RES, OXFORD INSTRUMENTS INC, TEKTRONIX INC, UNIV OREGON
ID NUCLEAR HEAT-CAPACITY; LA2-XBAXCUO4; TRANSITION; MOMENTS;
   SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; TEMPERATURE
AB Zero field muon spin rotation (mu)SR) is applied to La2-xM(x)CuO4 (M=Ba, Sr) around x=0.12.  Observation of the clear precession of the asymmetry pattern indicates the magnetic order of Cu-moments around x=0.12 where superconductivity is suppressed remarkably.  Magnetic phase diagram is determined.

TI MUON RADIOLYSIS IN ALKALI-HALIDES
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
ID QUANTUM DIFFUSION; KBR
AB In order to shed new light on the initial loss of muon spin polarization, or so-called ''missing fraction'', which is commonly observed in non-metallic solids, we have studied muon-induced excitation in various alkali halides by measuring the lu-minescences associated with the radiative decay of the self-trapped excitons (STE). The result strongly suggests that the spin-exchange interaction between muonium and muon radiolysis products including STE's causes fast muon depolarization in those materials.

TI ULTRA-SLOW MUON FACILITY FOR ADVANCED MU-SR STUDIES
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
ID VACUUM
AB A concept, a construction and an account of commissioning experiments up to May 1993 are given for the recently completed ultra-slow positive muon facility at the pulsed muon facility of UT-MSL/KEK. The intense aiid ultra-slow mu+ beam with an extremely small phase-space volume to be produced iii this facility will open new muon sciences including muSR studies on material surfaces.

TI CONSTRUCTION OF RIKEN-RAL MUON FACILITY AT ISIS AND ADVANCED MU-SR
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
ID KEK
AB By utilizing the intense pulsed proton beam available at the ISIS facility of RAL, the new muon facility project of an advanced superconducting muon channel funded by the RIKEN is now under construction. The new facility, by adopting the superconducting solenoid system, will produce the strongest backward decay pulsed mu+ or mu- in the momentum range from 20 MeV/c to 120 MeV/c. Also, by adopting the pulsed magnetic kicker, each one of two muon pulses will be supplied to two extraction channels simultaneously. Various important muon science experiments including advanced pulsed mu- SR and mu+ SR experiments will be realized.

TI MU-SR AND NMR INVESTIGATIONS ON ELECTRONIC AND MAGNETIC STATE AROUND
   X=0.12 IN LA2-XSRXCUO4 AND LA2-XBAXCUO4
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
ID TEMPERATURE STRUCTURAL TRANSITION; NUCLEAR HEAT-CAPACITY; CU SPIN
   MOMENTS; PHASE-TRANSITIONS; SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; ANOMALIES;
   (LA1-XBAX)2CUO4; TRANSPORT; ROTATION; ORDER
AB The muon spin rotation (mu+SR) and NMR measurements provides clear evidences of the antiferromagnetic order of Cu-moment below 35 K for La2-xBaxCuO4 and below 15 K for La2-xSrxCuO4 in the narrow range of x where the high-T(C) superconductivity (SC) is suppressed remarkably. The results suggest that the freezing of spin fluctuations of Cu-moment is relevant to the local suppression of SC under an change of the electronic state coupled with the lattice instability.

TI MU(+)SR AND MOSSBAUER-SPECTROSCOPY ON OXYGEN-HOMOGENIZED SEMICONDUCTING
   SEMICONDUCTING YBA2(CU1-XFEX)3O6+DELTA
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
AB Mu+SR and Fe-57 Mossbauer spectroscopy on semiconducting YBaCuO reveal that oxygen homogenization leads to an enhanced low-dimensional clustering of Fe mainly in Cu(1). The magnetic order of Cu(2) is less sensitive to iron doping than for not homogenized samples.
C1 MESON SCI LAB,TOKYO,JAPAN.
   YAMANASHI UNIV,KOFU,YAMANASHI 400,JAPAN.

TI OBSERVATION OF MAGNETIC ORDER OF CU-MOMENT AROUND X=0.12 IN LA2-XBAXCUO4
   AND LA2-XSRXCUO4 BY MU(+)SR
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
ID STRUCTURAL TRANSITION; PHASE; ANOMALIES
AB Zero field positive muon spin rotation method (mu+SR) is applied on La2-xSrxCuO4 around for x=0.12 at which the high-T(c) superconductivity (SC) is suppressed. The magnetically ordered state of Cu-moments, which is not a spin glass state but an antiferromagnetic like state, appears below 15 K for 0.105 less-than-or-equal-to x less-than-or-equal-to 0.120. The magnetic phase boundary is very similar to the one of the La2-xBaCuO4 in which the structural transition from the low temperature orthorhombic (LTO) phase to the low temperature tetragonal (LTT) phase is observed around x=0.12. The present study suggests that there is no big difference of the electronic state of the CuO2 plane between the La-Ba system and the La-Sr system and that the magnetic ordering of Cu-moments plays an important role for the suppression of the high-T(c) SC around x=0.12 in both of the systems, although the LTO-LTT structural transition has not been observed yet in the La-Sr system.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.
   HOKKAIDO UNIV,FAC SCI,DEPT PHYS,SAPPORO,HOKKAIDO 060,JAPAN.

TI A STUDY OF DIAMAGNETIC MUON BONDING IN ALPHA-QUARTZ USING MUON
   SPIN-RESONANCE
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
ID GLASSES; SILICA; WATER; H-1
AB Diamagnetic muon spin resonance experiments were carried out in a-quartz at two temperatures: 300 K and 130 K. A strong diamagnetic resonance peak was observed at both temperatures. The spectrum exhibits an anisotropy in the chemical shift of 15 ppm (300 K) and 25 ppm (130 K).

TI QUANTUM DIFFUSION OF MUONIUM IN GAAS WITH SHALLOW DONOR IMPURITIES
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
ID LIGHT INTERSTITIALS; ANOMALOUS MUONIUM; POSITIVE MUONS; METALS; COPPER;
   KCL
AB Muonium diffusion was studied in silicon doped GaAs by means of muon spin relaxation in a longitudinal field. The muonium hopping frequencies in two samples with n-type carrier concentration of 10(12-14) cm-3 and 8 x 10(16) cm-3 were deduced by using the model of fluctuating effective local fields. We found that muonium diffusion is strongly influenced by the dilute Si impurity in both samples in the temperature range below T(DELTA) congruent-to 30 K. The absence of such a behavior in compensated high-resistivity samples indicates that the presence of shallow donor levels plays a decisive role for the tunneling diffusion of muonium in semiconductors.

TI SPIN DYNAMICS OF THE 2-DIMENSIONAL FERROMAGNETISM IN THE SUPERLATTICE
   [MNSB/SB] PROBED BY POSITIVE MUONS
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
ID KEK
AB The spin dynamics of 2-dimensional ferromagnetic monolayers of [MnSb/Sb] were studied by the mu+SR method using pulsed sub-surface muons with a momentum of 18 - 25 MeV/c. A gradual growth of a static field along the mu+ spin below 200 K and a divergent increase of the relaxation rate at around 25 K were observed in the 1 monolayer sample, related to the critical fluctuations in this magnetic superlattice.

TI ZERO-FIELD MU-SR STUDY OF CERU2SI2 HEAVY-FERMION COMPOUND
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 6th International Conference on Muon Spin Rotation/Relaxation/Resonance
CY MAY 31-JUN 11, 1993
CL MAUI, HI
AB Zero - field muon spin relaxation measurements have been carried out on a high-quality single-crystal sample of the paramagnetic heavy-fermion compound CeRu2Si2 from 5K to 300K. The observed relaxation at each temperature was well fitted by a function described by the product of a Kubo-Toyabe type and an exponential one. The temperature dependence of the Kubo-Toyabe relaxation rate sigma(ZF) shows an almost constant value (0.03 mus-1) which is comparable to the calculated linewidth due to nuclear dipole fields from Ru-99 and Ru-101) atoms assuming the possible mu+ stopping sites for the ThCr2Si2 structure. On the other hand, we observed an increase of the exponential relaxation rate lambda(ZF) to a value of congruent-to 0.02 mus-1 with decreasing temperature below about 100K. This suggests a contribution of Ce 4f moments.

TI THEORY OF LOCATION AND ASSOCIATED HYPERFINE PROPERTIES OF THE POSITIVE
   MUON IN LA2CUO4
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article
ID NUCLEAR-QUADRUPOLE INTERACTIONS; HIGH-TC SUPERCONDUCTORS; SPIN-ROTATION;
   MAGNETIC-RESONANCE; TRANSITION-TEMPERATURE; MOSSBAUER-SPECTROSCOPY;
   ELECTRON DISTRIBUTIONS; CU; YBA2CU3O7-DELTA; RELAXATION
AB The current understanding regarding the location of the positive muon, which is a valuable tool for probing the magnetic properties of copper oxide superconducting systems, will be reviewed for La2CuO4. The results of our present investigations by the Unrestricted Hartree-Fock Cluster procedure, which leads to a location for the muon of about 1.08 angstrom away from an apical oxygen and with the O-mu+ direction making an angle of 25-degrees with the O-Cu direction, will be discussed, including the magnitude and direction of the hyperfine field obtained from the calculated wave functions. These latter results. which are in reasonable agreement with earlier muon spin rotation data in powdered samples and recent data in single crystals, show the importance of including the local contact and dipolar contributions to the hyperfine field associated with the unpaired electron spin distribution in the neighborhood of the muon. Possible additional factors besides those included here, that will involve substantial computational efforts but could lead to a bridging of the remaining quantitative differences with experimental hyperfine data, will be discussed.

   YAMANASHI UNIV,DEPT ELECT ENGN & COMP SCI,KOFU,YAMANASHI 400,JAPAN.
   UNIV TOKYO,MESON SCI LAB,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI MU(+)SR STUDY OF ISING SPIN-GLASS FE0.5MN0.5TIO3
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article
AB A typical Ising spin-glass Fe0.5Mn0.5TiO3 has been investigated by mu+ spin relaxation measurements. It is found that the local magnetic fields at the mu+ stopping sites appear at a temperature twice as high as T(SG). The directional distribution of the local magnetic fields is nearly isotropic, indicating the existence of the transverse spin components. It is clearly demonstrated that the spins fluctuate below T(SG) and even at approximately 4 K. Taking into account the results obtained by other methods, the main part of the fluctuations is inferred to be due to the transverse spin components and the fluctuation times at approximately 4 K are driven into a range between approximately 10(-5) and approximately 10(-7) S.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.
   OCHANOMIZU UNIV,FAC SCI,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 112,JAPAN.

TI MUONIUM FORMATION AND MIGRATION IN CSMGCL3
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article
ID MU
AB The mu+SR were measured on CsMgCl3 single crystals to elucidate the muonium formation and migration in isostructural magnetic halides. More than 60% of incident mu+ were found to form muonium and the fraction of the muonium shows little temperature dependence. A part of muonium located near Mg2+ ions with zero nuclear dipole moments gives a fast relaxing component in the spectra. It was concluded from the decrease of asymmetry and the peak of the relaxation rate of the recovered asymmetry that muonium migrates above 90 K.

TI RELAXED EXCITED-STATES AND ANOMALOUS HYPERFINE-STRUCTURE OF MUONIUM
   CENTERS IN KBR
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article
ID SELF-TRAPPED EXCITON; INTRINSIC LUMINESCENCE; ALKALI-HALIDES; CRYSTALS
AB We report on the luminescence induced by positive muons implanted (with 4 MeV) into KBr crystal, which evidences a long-lived (lifetime = 13.3 mus) excited state produced by muon radiolysis. The temperature dependence of the luminescence yield has a strong correlation with the amplitude of an ''anomalous'' muonium center: both are observed only below approximately 50 K. This correlation strongly suggests that the muonium center is perturbed by the muon-induced excitons to cause the anomalous hyperfine structure. Moreover, the luminescence energy and decay time indicate that the observed luminescence is not associated with the intrinsic or impurity-related self-trapped excitons, but with a relaxed excited state specific to the muon(ium)-KBr system.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI POSITIVE MUONS IN SPIN-CROSSOVER COMPLEX [FE(NCS)2(PHEN)2]
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article
AB Diamagnetic muon species in a spin-crossover complex diisothiocyanatobisphen-anthrolineiron(II) were investigated: two species with different spin relaxation functions and rates were observed over the range from 21 to 293 K. The sum of their yields changed at about the spin transition temperature of the complex, where the spin state of the complex changes from paramagnetic to diamagnetic when it is cooled down across the temperature. The results suggest that paramagnetic muon species could exhibit diamagnetic muon-like muSR signals in paramagnetic environment.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,HONGO,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI POSITIVE MUONS IN [CO(NH3)6]CL3 AND [CO(ND3)6]CL3
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article
AB We have carried out muSR experiments on [Co(NH3)6]Cl3 and [Co(ND3)6]Cl3. At 293 K, all the muons implanted into the complexes were in the diamagnetic state. The observed Gaussian-type muon spin relaxation function proved that the internal magnetic field was caused by nuclear dipole moments of the atoms in the complexes. In addition, another exponential-type muon spin relaxation function was observed in [Co(ND3)6]Cl3 below 50 K.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,BUNKYO KU,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI SPIN DYNAMICS IN THE 2-DIMENSIONAL FERROMAGNETIC SUPERLATTICE [MNSB/SB]
   PROBED BY POSITIVE MUON SPIN ROTATION
SO JOURNAL OF MAGNETISM AND MAGNETIC MATERIALS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 1ST INTERNATIONAL SYMP ON METALLIC MULTILAYERS ( MML 93 )
CY MAR 01-05, 1993
CL KYOTO, JAPAN
SP JAPAN INST MET, RES INST PROD DEV
ID KEK
AB The spin dynamics of the 2-dimensional ferromagnetic monolayer (ML) of [MnSb/Sb] have been studied by the positive muon spin rotation method. We observed a divergent increase in the relaxation rate at around 25 K in the 1 ML sample, and a broad peak at around 250 K in the 2 ML one, related to the critical fluctuation in magnetic superlattices.

TI MU-SR STUDY OF THE HEAVY-ELECTRON SYSTEM CE(RU1-XRHX)2SI2
SO PHYSICA B-CONDENSED MATTER
LA English
DT Article
ID CERU2SI2; BEHAVIOR
AB We have performed zero- and longitudinal-field muSR measurements on polycrystalline Ce(Ru1-xRhx)2Si2 for x = 0 and 0.15 from 4 to 300 K. The development of a magnetic correlation has been found to start as high as room temperature for both systems with a quasistatic character. Another static inhomogeneous field partly occurs at 5.5 K for x = 0.15, suggesting a complicated antiferromagnetic ordering.

TI X-RAY STUDIES ON MUON TRANSFER-REACTIONS FROM HYDROGEN TO HELIUM
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Workshop on Muon Catalysed Fusion
CY JUN 28-JUL 03, 1992
CL UPPSALA, SWEDEN
SP EUROPEAN PHYS SOC, ROYAL SWEDISH ACAD SCI, NOBEL COMM PHYS, SWEDISH NAT SCI RES COUNCIL, SWEDISH INST, MUNICIPAL COUNCIL UPPSALA CITY, UPPSALA UNIV, DEPT QUANTUM CHEM
HO UPPSALA UNIV
AB We have experimentally studied the muon transfer reactions from hydrogen to helium in liquid hydrogen with helium impurity concentration around 100-1000 ppm. The X-ray from the decay of (dHe-4mu) molecule was clearly observed in the D2-He-4 system, whereas the corresponding X-ray was very weak in other systems such as D2-He-3 and H-2-He-4. This is well explained by the particle decay mode of the muonic molecule.

TI X-RAY-MEASUREMENT ON MUON TO ALPHA-STICKING IN MUON-CATALYZED D-T FUSION
   - PRESENT AND FUTURE
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Workshop on Muon Catalysed Fusion
CY JUN 28-JUL 03, 1992
CL UPPSALA, SWEDEN
SP EUROPEAN PHYS SOC, ROYAL SWEDISH ACAD SCI, NOBEL COMM PHYS, SWEDISH NAT SCI RES COUNCIL, SWEDISH INST, MUNICIPAL COUNCIL UPPSALA CITY, UPPSALA UNIV, DEPT QUANTUM CHEM
HO UPPSALA UNIV
ID REACTIVATION; HELIUM
AB Among a series of X-ray experiments on the muon catalyzed fusion (muCF) carried out by using pulsed muons at UTMSL/KEK, a direct knowledge of alpha-sticking probability (omega(s)) in muCF of high density D-T mixture with high T concentration has been obtained by measuring a characteristic muonic X-ray from the (alphamu) atoms (central energy of 8.2 keV with a correct Doppler broadening). Combining with the recent X-ray measurements in (dmu) to He-3 and He-4 impurities, new insight is now obtained for the detailed background structure in the X-ray spectrum, suggesting the future direction for the X-ray measurements.

TI SLOW AND MONOENERGETIC (HE-3-MU-)+ BEAM PRODUCTION AND NOVEL
   APPLICATIONS
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Workshop on Muon Catalysed Fusion
CY JUN 28-JUL 03, 1992
CL UPPSALA, SWEDEN
SP EUROPEAN PHYS SOC, ROYAL SWEDISH ACAD SCI, NOBEL COMM PHYS, SWEDISH NAT SCI RES COUNCIL, SWEDISH INST, MUNICIPAL COUNCIL UPPSALA CITY, UPPSALA UNIV, DEPT QUANTUM CHEM
HO UPPSALA UNIV
ID MU
AB Based upon the recent discovery at UT MSL/KEK, a new idea is proposed for producing a slow and monoenergetic (3.2 keV) (He-4mu-)+ ion beam by using particle decay of the (dHe-3mu) muon molecule formed during the (dmu) to He-3 transfer reaction. The proposed intense (He-3mu) beam as well as the less intense (He-4mu) beam will open up way to various new types of important mu CF experiments.

TI TOWARDS SLOW MU-PRODUCTION VIA MUON-CATALYZED FUSION
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Workshop on Muon Catalysed Fusion
CY JUN 28-JUL 03, 1992
CL UPPSALA, SWEDEN
SP EUROPEAN PHYS SOC, ROYAL SWEDISH ACAD SCI, NOBEL COMM PHYS, SWEDISH NAT SCI RES COUNCIL, SWEDISH INST, MUNICIPAL COUNCIL UPPSALA CITY, UPPSALA UNIV, DEPT QUANTUM CHEM
HO UPPSALA UNIV
AB Slow mu- production via dd-muCF using a two-layer arrangement is investigated. To determine its feasibility, experimental measurements are now in progress using the muonic X-ray detection method. The following experimental steps are being considered: (1) measurement of the number of mu- stopped inside a solid H2/D2 layer by detecting pmu K(alpha) X-rays, (2) ''hot'' dmu emission detection by placing a secondary target at a distance of 10-30 mm from the layer and by detecting specific delayed X-rays, (3) measurement of the disappearance of dmu emission as the added D2 layer is increased, (4) dd-muCF measurement by detecting fusion protons, and (5) slow mu- emission detection. Results of the initial test experiment are presented.

TI FUTURE MU-CF PROGRAM WITH PULSED MUONS AT UTMSL KEK AND RIKEN RAL
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Workshop on Muon Catalysed Fusion
CY JUN 28-JUL 03, 1992
CL UPPSALA, SWEDEN
SP EUROPEAN PHYS SOC, ROYAL SWEDISH ACAD SCI, NOBEL COMM PHYS, SWEDISH NAT SCI RES COUNCIL, SWEDISH INST, MUNICIPAL COUNCIL UPPSALA CITY, UPPSALA UNIV, DEPT QUANTUM CHEM
HO UPPSALA UNIV
ID FACILITY
AB The present paper summarizes new experimental proposals on muon catalyzed fusion (muCF) research with a sharply pulsed negative muon beam now available at the UTMSL/KEK facility and soon to be available in a more extensive way at the RIKEN/RAL facility. Special emphasis is placed on (1) muCF studies on ultra-pure D-T mixture, (2) slow mu- beam production via muCF, and (3) some exotic muCF phenomena.

TI ULTRA-SLOW MUON FACILITY FOR SURFACE HFI STUDIES
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference 34 / 9th International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions ( HFI-IX )
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
HO OSAKA UNIV, FAC SCI, DEPT PHYS & LAB NUCL STUDIES
ID VACUUM
AB A concept, a design, a construction and an account of commissioning experiments are given for the recently completed ultra-slow muon facility at the pulsed muon facility of UT-MSL/KEK. The intense (more than 10(3)/s) slow mu+ beam with an extremely narrow phase-space volume (0.2 eV x(3 cm)2) to be produced in this facility will open a new muon science including surface physics and chemistry and fundamental atomic physics.

TI A PROPOSAL FOR NEW SURFACE MAGNETISM STUDIES WITH A REPOLARIZATION
   METHOD
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference 34 / 9th International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions ( HFI-IX )
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
HO OSAKA UNIV, FAC SCI, DEPT PHYS & LAB NUCL STUDIES
AB A new spectroscopic method to study surface magnetism is proposed. The method measures the time-evolution of spin polarization due to the magnetic coupling with polarized electron spins of ''unpolarized'' and ''slow'' radioactive probes. Because of the expectedly high sensitivity and efficiency, a large field of applications will be opened by using slow positive muons, B-12 nuclei, etc.

TI ANISOTROPIC PARAMAGNETIC SHIFT OF MU(-)O IN THE HIGH T-C RELATED
   MATERIALS LASRCUO AND LACUO
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference XXXIV, The IXth International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions (HFI-IX)
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
ID SUPERCONDUCTOR
AB The negative muon (mu(-)) was used as a microscopic probe for the study of the electronic state at the oxygen site in high T-c related LaSrCuO materials. Using good single crystals, two types of signals are obtained corresponding to two different oxygen sites: one highly anisotropic, which shows a large (order of 1%) shift under the magnetic field in e-axis direction, the other less anisotropic and with a smaller amplitude (order of 0.2%). These results of mu(-)OSR show quit a difference with the result of O-17-NMR, where the paramagnetic shift has axial symmetry along the Cu-O bond direction and a magnitude of the order of 0.2% and 0.05%.

TI TEMPERATURE-DEPENDENCE OF (MU(-)O) PARAMAGNETIC SHIFT IN HIGH T-C
   SUPERCONDUCTOR LA2-XSRXCUO4
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference XXXIV, The IXth International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions (HFI-IX)
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
AB In order to investigate the electronic structure around oxygen in superconducting La2-xSrxCuO4 (x = 0.10 and 0.14), precise measurements were carried out on the paramagnetic Knight shifts in the spin rotation frequency of the negative muon bound to the oxygen with reference to antiferromagnetic La2-xSrxCuO4 (x = 0.05). Remarkable temperature as well as crystalline-axis dependence was observed for the high T-c case with a divergence character towards T-c. Possible mechanisms to explain the observed results are given.

TI LOCATION AND ASSOCIATED HYPERFINE PROPERTIES OF MU(+) IN LA2CUO4
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference XXXIV, The IXth International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions (HFI-IX)
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
ID MUON-SPIN ROTATION; ANTIFERROMAGNETISM; SR
AB The location of the positive muon used as a probe in high T-c systems is investigated using the unrestricted Hartree-Fock cluster procedure. Our calculations indicate that mu(+) is located in the alpha-c plane at a distance of 1.08 Angstrom from the apical oxygen at a mu(+)-O(a)-Cu angle of 25 degrees. The hyperfine field at this site is also calculated. Our results show the importance of including the local contact and dipolar contributions to the hyperfine field which arise from the unpaired electron spin distribution in the vicinity of the muon.
C1 SUNY ALBANY,DEPT PHYS,ALBANY,NY 12222.

TI COEXISTENCE OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY AND MAGNETISM IN SINGLE-CRYSTALLINE
   HIGH T-C SUPERCONDUCTOR LA2-XSRXCUO4 REVEALED BY THE MUON SPIN
   RELAXATION METHOD
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference XXXIV, The IXth International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions (HFI-IX)
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
ID LA1.85SR0.15CUO4; TRANSITION
AB The positive muon (mu(+)) spin relaxation method under zero external field is applied to probe magnetic ordering in the superconducting phase of a high quality single crystal of La2_xSrxCuO4 (0.10 < x < 0.15). A series of well characterized crystals with nearly complete flux exclusion were found to exhibit a magnetic ordering with transition temperature depending on x with a peak at x = O.11. Possible explanations are given.

TI LOCAL HYPERFINE FIELD VECTOR OF POSITIVE MUON IN MONO-DOMAIN
   SINGLE-CRYSTAL OF ANTIFERROMAGNETIC LA2CUO4
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference XXXIV, The IXth International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions (HFI-IX)
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
AB By using a monodomain single crystal La2CuO4 grown by the travelling solvent floating zone method, the strength and direction of the local hyperfine field vector at positive muon sites were determined. Combining with the mu(+) location determined separately, we found the importance of the local hyperfine field contributions with dipolar symmetry as well as the distant dipolar field from surrounding point dipoles of Cu atomic moments.

TI BEHAVIOR OF POSITIVE MUONS IN HIGH T-C SUPERCONDUCTORS LA2-XSRXCUO4
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference XXXIV, The IXth International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions (HFI-IX)
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
ID SR2CUO2CL2; LA2CUO4
AB An unambiguous determination of the mu(+) location in the high T-c LaSrCuO superconductor is made through zero-field spin relaxation in the paramagnetic phase and its crystal axis dependence by using single crystalline samples. The temperature dependence of the relaxation rates has a maximum between 80 and 150 K, indicating the existence of the onset of quantum diffusion at low temperature.

TI COMPETITION OF MAGNETIC ORDER AND SUPERCONDUCTIVITY INVESTIGATED BY
   POSITIVE MUON SPIN ROTATION IN LA(2-X)M(X)CUO(4) (M=BA, SR) AROUND
   X=0.12
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference XXXIV, The IXth International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions (HFI-IX)
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
ID STRUCTURAL PHASE-TRANSITION; NUCLEAR HEAT-CAPACITY; LOW-TEMPERATURE
   PHASE; LA2-XBAXCUO4; ANOMALIES; MOMENTS; TRANSPORT
AB Muon spin rotation(mu SR) is applied to La2_xBaxCuO4 around x = 0.12 where the superconductivity (SC) is suppressed remarkably. The magnetic ordering of Cu-moments appears below 35 K in the narrow range of x where a lattice instability from the low temperature orthorhombic (LTO) to the low-temperature tetragonal (LTT) structure exists. The present study suggests strongly that the magnetic ordering of Cu-moments is an important factor in the suppression of high-T-c superconductivity around x = 0.12 in La2-xBaxCuO4. Similar results are obtained for the La2-xSrxCUO4 and La2-x-ySrxNdyCuO4 systems.
C1 RIKEN,WAKO,SAITAMA 35101,JAPAN.
   UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.
RP KUMAGAI, K (reprint author), HOKKAIDO UNIV,FAC SCI,DEPT PHYS,SAPPORO,HOKKAIDO 060,JAPAN.

TI MUONIUM EMISSION AND REACTION ON PLATINUM AND GOLD POWDER SURFACES
   REVEALED BY MUSR
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference 34 / 9th International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions ( HFI-IX )
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
HO OSAKA UNIV, FAC SCI, DEPT PHYS & LAB NUCL STUDIES
AB Muonium has been observed in powdered platinum (30 nm diameter) and gold (100 nm diameter), respectively, placed in vacuum by the muonium spin rotation (MuSR) technique at ambient temperature. Upon introducing gaseous oxygen up to 23 Torr into platinum powder, the muonium signal was eliminated, indicating that the observed muonium stays outside the platinum particles. The result on the platinum surface treated by hydrogen but exposed to oxygen gas suggests a reactive collision between muonium and oxygen adsorbed atomically on the surface.
C1 UNIV TOKYO,FAC SCI,MESON SCI LAB,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.
RP MATSUSHITA, A (reprint author), RIKEN,WAKO,SAITAMA 35101,JAPAN.

TI MU+SR STUDY OF 2-DIMENSIONAL ANTIFERROMAGNETS, DELAFOSSITE-TYPE
   COMPOUNDS
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference 34 / 9th International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions ( HFI-IX )
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
HO OSAKA UNIV, FAC SCI, DEPT PHYS & LAB NUCL STUDIES
ID MU
AB Mu+SR experiments were performed on delafossite-type compounds, CuCrO2, AgCrO2, CuFeO2, which are model compounds of triangular lattice antiferromagnets. The initial asymmetries are much smaller than the expected value, implying muonium formation. The time spectra are composed of slow and fast relaxation components. We attributed the components to signals from mu+ stopped at the center of O2- ions and muonium far from nuclear dipole moments, respectively. The asymmetries decrease below T(N) but no precession spectra were observed. Relaxation rates of slow and fast relaxation components show maxima at T(N).
C1 UNIV TOKYO,DEPT PHYS,MSL,TOKYO 113,JAPAN.

TI SPIN DYNAMICS IN A SITE-DILUTED FINITE SPIN CLUSTER SYSTEM PROBED BY
   POSITIVE MUONS
SO HYPERFINE INTERACTIONS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT Yamada Conference 34 / 9th International Conference on Hyperfine
   Interactions ( HFI-IX )
CY AUG 17-21, 1992
CL TOYONAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
HO OSAKA UNIV, FAC SCI, DEPT PHYS & LAB NUCL STUDIES
ID ANTI-FERROMAGNETS
AB The site diluted finite spin cluster system Rb2CoxMg1-xF4 (x = 0.15, 0.4, 0.5) has been investigated by the mu+SR technique. Muon spin relaxation was observed in these diluted magnetic systems in a weak longitudinal field of 100 G. By reducing temperature below 100 K, the experimental data show features of slowing down phenomena of the Co electron moments in the finite spin clusters.
